depends on what you change.  The  config file has settings that grub uses,, then the special #commented settings - that update-grub uses..
be sure to backup your existing config. :)

ive seen that error befor.. but dont rember what it means. You may want to check the grub homepage/manual and learn some more grub essentials.  and yes.. ive fought with grub/lilo over the ages.. and it can be frustrating. :)
i would say either the  grub config is looking at the wrong filesystem, or the filesystem is currupted.  from what i am reading.
since I just removed one partition I think that sounds reasonable... but I alredy edited menu.lst to fix it...
you do rember that grub starts Numbering at 0? :)
also dont try to boot a extended partition.. but the logical IN the extended.
ive lerned from accidently trying to doo all this in the past. :P
i think I have three primary partitions --> http://rafb.net/p/37ySVg40.html   looks correct, no?
did you 'resize' these partitions with  gparted?  thers a gap in the Numbering of the cylinders I notice..
nah, I used the built in partition resize in Vista to shrink my NTFS partition and then I also removed another NTFS partition completely
so you just deleted some partitions in the middle. (thats why the #'s jump) eh?  Its possible the uuid's have changed. but i think thats only if you rezise the linux partitions.

I believe there should be a big gap because I left unpartitioned space... because I wanted to let windows modify the NTFS and then let gparted expand my ext2 partitions later on (I wanted to let each tool do only what it does best)
you could just try making a empty partition in the middle... :)  or use the grubs shell to 'find' the location of the  boot files.  and get the proper hd #.,#
so the empty space was still being numbered? goofing you up?  or what exactly webt wrong?

since I deleted one my NTFS partitions the index in menu.lst was wrong... my linux partition used to be (hd0,2) but when I deleted the extra NTFS partition I had my linux partition at (hd0,1) instead.... I had already figured out how to boot a livecd and update the menu.lst chaning (hd0,2) into (hd0,1) but that was not sufficient.... the final step that fixed it for me was starting the grub command line tool using "sudo grub" and then running
